P: 1, female, 10, 54, 46
S:lumps in neck
S:Butterfly rash
S:Lung disease
R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 60,  The presence of a butterfly rash and lung disease are common manifestations of SLE, an autoimmune disorder that can affect multiple organ systems, including the skin, joints, and lungs.
R: 2, Lymphoma, 20,  The lumps in the neck could be swollen lymph nodes, which can be a sign of lymphoma, a type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system.
R: 3, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 10,  While not specifically mentioned, joint pain and swelling are common symptoms of JIA, an autoimmune disorder that can also cause rashes and lung involvement in some cases.
R: 4, Sarcoidosis, 5,  This inflammatory disorder can cause lung disease and swollen lymph nodes, although the butterfly rash is less common in sarcoidosis.
R: 5, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 5,  This autoimmune disorder can cause a rash similar to the butterfly rash, as well as lung disease and muscle weakness, although swollen lymph nodes are less common.

R: 3, Lymphoma, 10,  The lumps in the neck, enlarged liver and spleen, and shortness of breath could suggest a form of lymphoma, a type of blood cancer.
R: 4, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 5,  The rash, joint swelling, and muscle weakness (indicated by shortness of breath) could point to juvenile dermatomyositis, an autoimmune condition affecting the skin and muscles.
R: 5, Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), 5,  The presence of blood in urine, joint swelling, and sores in the mouth could be signs of HSP, a type of vasculitis that can affect children.

R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 40,  Joint pain, proteinuria, and abnormal liver function are common manifestations of SLE, which is an autoimmune disorder that can affect multiple organ systems.

R: 4, Kawasaki Disease, 10,  Kawasaki disease is a rare childhood illness that can cause joint pain, chest pain, and abnormal liver function tests.

R: 2, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 20,  The presence of rash, muscle weakness/pain, and potential lung involvement could indicate juvenile dermatomyositis, an inflammatory muscle disease.
R: 3, Wegener's Granulomatosis, 10,  The sores in the nose, lung disease, and potential kidney involvement (protein in urine) could suggest Wegener's granulomatosis, a rare autoimmune disorder affecting small blood vessels.
R: 4, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 5,  The overlapping symptoms of rash, joint pain, muscle weakness, and potential lung and kidney involvement could point towards MCTD, a combination of various autoimmune disorders.
R: 5, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 5,  The joint pain and potential systemic involvement could be indicative of JIA, a group of autoimmune disorders affecting joints and other organs in children.

R: 2, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 15,  The rash, fever, and muscle weakness (suggested by stomach pain) are consistent with this autoimmune condition affecting the skin and muscles.
R: 3, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 10,  The combination of rash, fever, and potential involvement of multiple organs (skin, kidneys, muscles) could suggest MCTD, an overlap syndrome with features of various autoimmune diseases.
R: 4, Vasculitis, 3,  The presence of rash, fever, and potential organ involvement (kidneys, gastrointestinal tract) could be indicative of a vasculitic disorder, which involves inflammation of blood vessels.
R: 5, Drug Reaction, 2,  Although less likely, the rash, fever, and potential organ involvement could be a manifestation of a severe drug reaction or hypersensitivity syndrome.

R: 4, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, 10,  Although rare in children, lupus can present with fever, rash, mouth sores, and muscle pain as part of a systemic autoimmune condition.
R: 5, Drug Reaction, 5,  Certain medications can cause a drug hypersensitivity reaction with fever, rash, mouth sores, and muscle aches as side effects.

R: 3, Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), 10,  The combination of joint pain, abdominal pain, and potential kidney involvement (proteinuria) could suggest this vasculitis condition, which is more common in children.
R: 4, Rheumatoid Arthritis, 5,  The joint pain and potential lung involvement could be indicative of this autoimmune disorder, although it is less common in children.
R: 5, Sarcoidosis, 5,  The combination of joint pain, lung disease, and potential spleen and kidney involvement could suggest this inflammatory condition, although it is relatively rare in children.

R: 5, Viral Hepatitis, 5,  Abnormal liver function, fever, and rash can be seen in viral hepatitis, although the joint pain and shortness of breath are less common.

R: 3, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 5,  The butterfly rash, joint pain, and shortness of breath (due to potential muscle weakness affecting respiratory muscles) can be seen in this autoimmune condition affecting the skin and muscles.
R: 4, Pulmonary Hypertension, 5,  Shortness of breath, chest pain, and fatigue (which can contribute to depression) can be symptoms of pulmonary hypertension, a condition characterized by high blood pressure in the lungs.
R: 5, Fibromyalgia, 5,  Joint pain, fatigue (which can contribute to depression), and chest pain (due to potential costochondritis) can be seen in fibromyalgia, a chronic pain condition.

S:Butterfly rash
S:Sores in nose
S:Hair thinning
S:Blood in urine
S:Abnormal liver function
R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 70,  The presence of fever, butterfly rash, joint pain, and abnormal liver function are characteristic symptoms of SLE, an autoimmune disorder that can affect multiple organ systems.
R: 2, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 50,  The joint pain, fever, and enlarged liver could be indicative of JIA, a type of arthritis that affects children and can involve organs beyond the joints.
R: 3, Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), 40,  The presence of blood in urine, joint pain, and fever could suggest HSP, a vasculitis disorder that can cause kidney involvement and rash.
R: 4, Autoimmune Hepatitis, 30,  The abnormal liver function, enlarged liver, and fever could be signs of autoimmune hepatitis, a chronic liver disease caused by an autoimmune reaction.
R: 5, Leukemia, 20,  The fever, enlarged liver, and blood in urine could potentially be caused by leukemia, a type of blood cancer that can affect various organs and systems.

S:Abnormal liver function
R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 60,  The presence of butterfly rash, joint pain, and abnormal liver function are characteristic symptoms of SLE, an autoimmune disorder.
R: 2, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 20,  Joint pain, weight loss, and the presence of lumps in the neck (possibly swollen lymph nodes) could indicate JIA, an autoimmune condition affecting children.
R: 3, Wegener's Granulomatosis, 10,  The combination of sores in the nose, blood in urine, and weight loss could suggest Wegener's Granulomatosis, a rare autoimmune disorder affecting small and medium-sized blood vessels.
R: 4, Lymphoma, 5,  The presence of lumps in the neck, weight loss, and abnormal liver function could potentially indicate a form of lymphoma, a type of blood cancer.
R: 5, Kidney Disease, 5,  Blood in urine and seizures could be indicative of underlying kidney disease, although other symptoms are not typical of most kidney disorders.

S:rash on face
R: 1, Lymphadenopathy, 40,  Lumps in the neck could indicate swollen lymph nodes, which can be caused by various conditions, including infections or immune disorders.
R: 2, Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema), 30,  The rash on the face, along with the patient's age and the presence of lymphadenopathy, could suggest atopic dermatitis, a common skin condition in children.
R: 3, Viral Infection (e.g., Mononucleosis, Measles), 15,  Viral infections like mononucleosis or measles can cause lymphadenopathy and rash, especially in children.
R: 4, Allergic Reaction, 10,  The rash and lymphadenopathy could be due to an allergic reaction to food, medication, or environmental triggers.
R: 5, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis, 5,  Although less common, juvenile idiopathic arthritis can sometimes present with lymphadenopathy and rash as initial symptoms.

R: 3, Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), 20,  HSP is a vasculitis that can cause fever, rash, abdominal pain (which may lead to splenomegaly), and kidney involvement with protein in urine.
R: 4, Leukemia, 5,  Fever, splenomegaly, and rash can be seen in some types of leukemia, although protein in urine is less common.
R: 5, Viral Infection (e.g., Epstein-Barr Virus, Cytomegalovirus), 5,  Viral infections can cause fever, rash, splenomegaly, and sometimes kidney involvement with protein in urine.

R: 2, Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), 30,  HSP is a vasculitis that can cause joint pain, hematuria, and pleuritis, and it is more common in children.
R: 3, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 15,  JIA can present with joint pain and stiffness, and some subtypes can involve extra-articular manifestations like pleuritis and hematuria.
R: 4, Wegener's Granulomatosis, 10,  This rare vasculitis can cause joint pain, hematuria, and pleuritis, although it is more common in adults.
R: 5, Rheumatic Fever, 5,  Rheumatic fever can cause joint pain and pleuritis, but hematuria is less common in this condition.

R: 2, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 20,  Joint swelling and stomach pain can be seen in JIA, a type of arthritis that occurs in children, and an enlarged spleen can sometimes occur due to the inflammatory process.
R: 3, Leukemia, 10,  An enlarged spleen (splenomegaly) can be a sign of leukemia, a type of blood cancer, and stomach pain may occur due to the disease or its treatment.
R: 4, Rheumatic Fever, 5,  Joint swelling and stomach pain can be symptoms of rheumatic fever, an inflammatory condition that can occur after a streptococcal infection, and an enlarged spleen is sometimes seen.
R: 5, Viral Infection, 5,  Certain viral infections, such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or cytomegalovirus (CMV), can cause an enlarged spleen, joint swelling, and stomach pain, although a butterfly rash is less common.

R: 5, Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), 5,  HUS is a rare condition that can cause fever, hematuria, and coughing up blood due to the breakdown of red blood cells and platelet consumption.

R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 70,  The presence of a butterfly rash, joint pain, mouth sores, and abnormal liver function are classic symptoms of SLE, an autoimmune disorder.
R: 2, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 15,  Joint pain and stiffness are common in JIA, an autoimmune condition affecting children, and it can also cause rashes and abdominal pain.
R: 3, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 8,  MCTD is an autoimmune disorder that can cause symptoms similar to SLE, including rashes, joint pain, and abnormal liver function.
R: 4, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 5,  This autoimmune condition can cause rashes, muscle weakness, and joint pain, and it can also affect the gastrointestinal system and liver.
